concern: So I wanna go to the film club at my college this semester and I joined the club and attended the first meeting last semester in the, but I never returned last semester du to being so busy with work. I'm not really freinds with any of the students in the club, so I'm worried it would be akward. On top of that I missed the first two meetings this semester thr first one they must have changed locations and I couldn't figure put when and the second one I got sick that week(awful time) should I still go to the other film club meeting and stuff? What should I do? I wanna make more friend but I feel like I'd be too nervous.

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! What's on your mind today?
I'm feeling anxious about rejoining a club on campus and interacting with new people. I want to make friends but I'm worried it might feel awkward.

It's totally normal to feel anxious about meeting new people and putting yourself out there. Making friends can be nerve-wracking, but it's also a great way to build connections and expand your social circle. Is there anything specific you're worried about when it comes to interacting with new people?

I'm worried about feeling out of place since I haven't been consistent with attending, which might make interactions awkward. Despite that, I'm eager to push through my nervousness to build those connections.

It sounds like you're caught between a rock and a hard placewanting to make friends, but feeling anxious about being out of the loop. That's a tough spot to be in. But it's really impressive that you're determined to push through your nervousness and give it a shot anyway. What's one thing you could do to help yourself feel a bit more comfortable when you show up to the club meeting?
I could prepare by reminding myself of my reasons for joining the club to build some confidence beforehand. That way, I might feel less nervous and more ready to engage with others.

That's a great idea! So, before your next club meeting, you could take a few minutes to review your reasons for joining and remind yourself of your goals. This might help boost your confidence and reduce some of the anxiety you're feeling. Would you like to give this strategy a try before your next meeting?
Yes, I'd like to give that strategy a try before my next meeting. It could help me feel more prepared and less nervous about connecting with others.

Great! It seems like you have a plan in place to help you feel more confident and less anxious at your next club meeting. Would you also like to think about some conversation starters or icebreakers that could help you engage with others more easily?
Yes, I'd like to think about some conversation starters to make engaging with others feel less intimidating. That could help me build confidence and ease into making new friends at the club.

It's great to see that you have a plan in place to help you feel more confident and less anxious at your next club meeting. Remember to review your reasons for joining the club and practice some conversation starters to make engaging with others easier. Keep in mind that feeling nervous is completely normal, and taking small steps can help you build confidence over time. I wish you the best of luck, and feel free to reach out again if you'd like to discuss your progress or any other concerns.
Thanks for the encouragement I'll practice those conversation starters and head to the next film club meeting to work on my nerves and make some new friends.
